Situation1: Their partner is going through a serious personal crisis and relies on them for consistent emotional reassurance and presence.
Expectation2: Meet sales targets set by management
Situation2: Midway through the week, their individual sales numbers are already on pace to surpass the quota.
Story: I sat at my desk, headset pressing into my ear, the hum of the office blending with the anxious thrum in my chest. My sales numbers blinked on the screen—already ahead of quota, but the manager’s words echoed: “Keep pushing, don’t let up.” I was supposed to be relentless, to ride this momentum and set a new record. But my phone buzzed again, a message from my wife. She was struggling, her world unraveling after the news about her father. She needed me—needed my words, my arms, my presence. I could picture her on the couch, eyes red, waiting for me to call, to come home early, to just be there. My manager’s expectations and my wife’s needs pulled at me from opposite sides. I stared at the blinking cursor, my heart torn, wondering which voice I should listen to.
